Department of Chemical Engineering Sri Sivasubramaniya Nadar College of Engineering Kalavakkam Tamil Nadu 603110 India The existence of azo dyes (BB and BG) in textile wastewater is a major problem owing to their possible effect on human health and the environment. In this work, we examine the photodegradation performance under the visible sources of BB and BG are Azo dyes extensively applied in the food and textile industries. An initial screening of dissimilar Ni-doped CdAl2O4 nanoparticles was determined to classify the most outstanding candidate for BB and BG removal. The Ni (0.075 M) doped CdAl2O4 nanoparticles after 90 min illuminations, 95 and 96% of BB and BG removal were noticed in pH =5 (acidic) and 5 mg catalyst dosage conditions. The recyclability of the Ni (0.075 M) doped CdAl2O4 catalyst was tested under optimized circumstances. The outcomes demonstrate that Ni (0.075 M) doped CdAl2O4 products exhibit substantially high stability with above 85 and 90% removal after the sixth catalytic run. The scavenging (free radicals) experiments revealed that .OH− and h + radicals play a central role in BB and BG degradation. Overall, the outcomes obtained propose that the suggested route may denote an appropriate technique for the elimination of BB and BG from textile wastes. This work shows the new pathway to improve more efficient materials for the elimination of industrial effluents. The primary ecological contaminants commonly encountered are pesticides, metal ions, aromatic compounds, pharmaceuticals, and organic/inorganic dyes [1]. Among them, inorganic/organic dye solutions are extensively applied in various industries like plastics, paint, tanneries, textile, and paper, which causes an everyday release of vast quantities of coloured wastes [2]. Organic/inorganic dyestuffs have lower biodegradability and are resistant to chemical reagents and heat. Furthermore, a maximum of them are regarded as carcinogenic components and mutagenic. Their existence in water bodies can also disturb the aquatic ecosystem [3,4], so the elimination of these contaminants from water bodies with sustainable and effective green approaches has become an essential task for researchers [5,6]. Dissimilar methods have been applied for dye elimination from water effluents, such as membrane filtration [7], reverse osmosis [8], adsorption [9], coagulation [10], ozone treatment [11], and photocatalytic degradation [12]. The Photocatalysis route is significantly probable in the remediation of the removal of inorganic/organic dyestuffs as it can completely mineralize inorganic/organic dyestuffs molecules into CO2 and H2O [13,14]. For this intent, dissimilar oxides materials like MnAl2O4 [15], CoAl2O4 [16], ZnAl2O4 [17], CaAl2O4 [18], MgAl2O4 [19], SrAl2O4 [20] and so are frequently applied. Generally, these mixed metal oxides materials have fascinated much attention owing to their numerous properties like, photocatalytic [16], magnetic [21], gas sensing [15], antibacterial activity [22], electrochemical performance [23], or applied in Li-ion batteries [24]. Tangcharoen et al., [25] reported the photocatalytic behavior of MAl2O4 (M = Zn, Ni, Cu) towards removing methylene blue, rhodamine B, methyl red and methyl orange. They determined that NiAl2O4 nanoparticles served as a superior catalyst compared to other materials. Maddahfar et al., [26] studied the NiAl2O4 nanoparticles fabricated using numerous gelling agents against MO dye and recorded 90% removal after the specified interval of visible illumination. Elakkiya et al., [27] described the Zn, Cu and Mg-NiAl2O4 nanoparticles as an effective photocatalyst against MO and MB removal under UV-light source. Rahimi-Nazrabadi et al., [28] studied the removal rate of MO dye toward NA under UV illumination. In particular, the CdAl2O4 materials have been broadly applied in many fields, like ceramics, catalysis, humidity sensor, and magnetic, due to their physical, thermal, and chemical stability [29]. Despite their suitable performance, the expanded applications of these oxides are restricted owing to the broad energy gap, rapid recombination of e −-h + pairs, and low activity under the visible range [30]. In addition, the CdAl2O4 spinel nanomaterials may be enhanced by varying the energy gap (3.7 eV). The energy gap of CdAl2O4 material can be modified by combining dopant ions with well-regulated optical performance, which proposes greater applicability in optical devices [31]. Also, doping with the Mn [32], Co [33], Ni [34], Zn [35], and Cr [36] ions can be the most vital tool to enhance the photoluminescence and photocatalytic performance of metal-aluminate materials. Several studies have described that combining metal ions into the MAl2O4 lattice improves various significant properties. Wu et al., [37] reported the energy gap of the product reductions with the enhancing Ni ion concentration. The reducing energy gap with Ni-doped ZnAl2O4 could be owing to introducing a new energy level (impurity or defect state) in the energy gap. Ercan et al., [38] investigated how adding Ni2+ ions has influenced both optical and magnetic properties, and the Ni-doped product revealed ferromagnetic behavior at RT (room temperature). Wang et al., [39] studied that adding nickel ions into ZnAl2O4 spinel materials improved its catalytic behavior. Yu et al., [40] studied that the Ni-doped ZnAl2O4 materials exhibited an excellent potential for usage in optical devices. Arunkumar et al., [41] found the enhanced photodegradation activity of MG (malachite green) dye detected in Ni-doped CoAl2O4 catalyst under the visible region. Numerous approaches have endeavoured for the fabrication of MAl2O4 spinel nanomaterials, such as mechanical alloying route [42], ball mill [43], solid-state reaction [44], co-precipitation [45], sol-gel [19], solution combustion [46] and solvothermal [17]. The co-precipitation route is an appropriate technique for preparing CdAl2O4 spinel nanomaterial of its high purity, homogeneity, and crystallinity. The photodegradation activity of CdAl2O4 toward organic/inorganic contaminants is still unidentified. Brilliant blue and Brilliant green are synthetic Azo dyes. BB and BG are water-soluble anionic and cationic dyes that appear as blue and green color powders [47]. These dyes are extensively applied in pharmaceutical, textile, and food industries produced through wastewater contamination. Its existence in water disturbs fauna, flora, and human. In addition, thus been studied that these toxic dyes may enter humans over fish through the food chain and may develop teratogenic, carcinogenic, and mutagenic effects on humans. So, the wastewater having BB and BG dyes should be decontaminated before releasing into fresh water. Therefore, the growth of the removal process is needed to ensure a clean and safe environment. Kinds of literature are obtainable for CdAl2O4 as a visible photocatalyst in eliminating dye stuff such as methylene blue, rhodamine b, and so on [48–51]. But, the degradation of BB and BG dyes from wastewater has yet to be examined. Therefore, we attempted to degrade BB and BG dyes using a Ni-doped CdAl2O4 catalyst under visible light illumination. Over the previous years, our research unit was attentive to exploring new binary oxide material to remove inorganic/organic contaminants by photocatalysis using visible/solar light illumination [52–56]. In this research, our selection is focused on a new binary oxide material that, to the best of our literature reports, has yet to be applied in photocatalytic activity, namely Ni-doped CdAl2O4 nanoparticles. The few research work observed in the survey is that of Bouhemadou [57], Slack [58], Ma [59], Candan [60], Wu, [61], Manzar [62] and Boujnah [63] about the various application properties. But Ni-CdAl2O4 performance under visible illumination against BB and BG dyes was not examined in detail. The current research deals with the co-precipitation approach successfully fabricated pure CdAl2O4 and Ni (0.025, 0.050, 0.075 M) doped CdAl2O4 materials. In the initial part, the obtained products are calcinated at 700 °C and analyzed by XRD, HR-TEM, UV-DRS, FT-IR, PL, and ESR spectroscopy. Next part, the photodegradation efficiencies of the Brilliant blue (BB) and Brilliant green (BB) dyes on the Ni-doped CdAl2O4 sample are evaluated under visible illumination. The consequence of catalyst dosage, pH effect, scavenger species, initial dye concentration, chemical oxygen demand, catalyst reusability and kinetic study were extensively studied. The mechanisms ruling the photodegradation properties of Ni (0.075 M) doped CdAl2O4 product are explained in the present study. We believe this research could contribute to upcoming design accesses for several inorganic/organic contaminants and additional reactions. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials All chemical substances applied for the preparation process, such as Cadmium acetate dehydrates (Cd(CH3COO)2·2H2O), Aluminium nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O), Nickel acetate (Ni(CH3CO2)2), Sodium hydroxide (NaOH), Brilliant blue (C37H34N2Na2O9S3) and Brilliant green (C27H34N2O4S) were of analytical grade bought from S.D fine chemical, India and utilized reagents without additional purification. Double distilled water (DDW) was applied for the sample fabrication and all dilutions. 2.2 Synthesis of CdAl2O4 and Ni-doped CdAl2O4 nanoparticles The co-precipitation process achieved the pure CdAl2O4 and Ni-doped CdAl2O4 nanoparticles, as described below. More accurately, the Aluminum nitrate (0.5 M) 9.377 g was dissolved into 50 mL of DDW with continual stirring at room temperature. Then, Cadmium acetate dehydrates (0.3 M) 3.990 g was mixed into 50 mL of DDW in a separate beaker. Next, the second reaction solution was added leisurely to the above solution with continuous stirring. After 10 min, the 0.025, 0.050, and 0.075 M of Nickel acetate were dissolved into 30 mL of DDW (separately). Simultaneously, these aqueous mixtures were added dropwise above the reaction mixtures. Afterwards, 0.2 M of Sodium hydroxide was dissolved into 30 mL of DDW and added slowly above the reaction mixture. Subsequently, the resulting solutions were vigorously stirred at 80 °C for 5 h. After 5 h, the resulting precipitate was filtered and washed with warm DDW and ethanol and then dried in a hot oven at 100 °C for 5 h. Finally, the dried powder was calcined at 700 °C for 5 h to obtain the Ni-doped CdAl2O4 product. The same process synthesized the CdAl2O4 nanoparticles. When the Ni-doped CdAl2O4 catalyst absorbs light sources (photons), an e − (electron) moves from the valance band (VB) to the conduction band (CB) and makes a jump to Ni new energy level, leaving an h + (hole) in VB (Eq. (4), (5)) [67,84]. The photogenerated h + VB can interact with surface OH groups or chemisorbed water to form hydroxyl radicals (.OH-) or can straight oxidize BB and BG dyes (Eq. (6)) [41]. Concurrently, photogenerated e− CB can interact with the surrounding O2 absorbed on Ni (0.075 M) doped CdAl2O4 catalyst surface to generate .O2 − (superoxide radicals) (Eq. (7)) [84]. Finally, these .OH and .O2 − radicals further react with the dye molecules (BB and BG) to photodegrade it completely (Eq. (8,9,10)) [67,92,93]. In the present research, introducing dopant Ni ions into CdAl2O4 reduced the energy gap. It increased the charge carrier separation, resulting in improved photodegrading of BB and BG dyes with Ni (0.075 M) doped CdAl2O4 catalyst [92–94]. The mechanism for the photodegradation of BB and BG dyes by Ni (0.075 M) doped CdAl2O4 can be elucidated in the following steps: (4) Ni -CdAl2O4 catalyst + light (hv) → Ni-CdAl2O4 (e − + h+ ) pairs (5) e − CB + O2 (Ni-CdAl2O4) → +.O2 − (6) h + VB (Ni-CdAl2O4) + OH (or H2O) → H + + .OH− (7) h + VB (Ni-CdAl2O4) + OH− → .OH (8) ·OH− + dyes (BB and BG) → Degraded products (H2O+ CO2) (9) h ++ dyes (BB and BG) → Degraded products (H2O+ CO2) (10) .O2 − + dyes (BB and BG) → Degraded products (H2O+ CO2) 3.10 Catalyst dosage To evade excess Ni (0.075 M) doped CdAl2O4 catalyst dosage and assure complete absorption of effectual light, a series of trials was accomplished to evaluate the optimum Ni (0.075 M) doped CdAl2O4 catalyst loading dosage by variable the quantity of the greatest photocatalyst (Ni (0.075 M) doped CdAl2O4) from 3 to 11 mg. Recycling runs for BB and BG dye molecules degradation under visible light illuminations were also accomplished (Fig. 6S). After every cycle test, the Ni (0.075 M) doped CdAl2O4 catalyst was filtered and washed with ethanol and DI water, and then the catalyst drying at 100 °C for 6 h. The experiment measures the absolute quantity of oxygen (O) needed to oxidize (.OH−, h +) the organic substance in effluents to H2O and CO2. Hence, COD was used to check the photodegradation of BB and BG dyes. The removal efficiencies of COD reduction are revealed in Table 2 . The percentage of COD degradation performance for the BB and BG dye solutions had enhanced up to 92 and 94 %, respectively. This outcome denotes almost complete degradation or mineralization of the BB and BG dye solutions. 4 Conclusion In summary, novel CdAl2O4 nanoparticles were developed using the substitution of Ni ions by a co-precipitation approach. The optical Eg values of CdAl2O4 nanoparticles are slightly reduced from 3.66 to 1.70 eV when increasing the nickel concentration. The PL measurements establish the emission in the CdAl2O4 and Ni-doped CdAl2O4 nanoparticles, owing to the interstitial defects and VO in the present samples. TEM images indicated that the surface morphology of Ni (0.075 M) CdAl2O4 nanoparticles exhibit a rod-like structure, and some particles are spherical with little agglomeration. The Ni (0.075 M) CdAl2O4 photocatalysts rendered the best photodegradation behaviours of about 95 and 96 %, respectively. Moreover, the influence of several parameters, like pH, catalyst dosage, reactive species, irradiation time, catalyst stability, reaction time and kinetic study, on the removal of BB and BG dye solutions was investigated. Also, the Ni (0.075 M) CdAl2O4 nanoparticles provided COD removal activity of 92 and 94 % in 90 min. The radical species are actively associated with the removal of BB and BG dye solutions of which .OH− and h + radicals played a leading role in the photodegradation process. Hence, these outcomes highlight that Ni-doped CdAl2O4 nanoparticles can be applied as a possible candidate for eliminating Azo dye molecules contained in industrial effluent. coredata.dc:description: The existence of azo dyes (BB and BG) in textile wastewater is a major problem owing to their possible effect on human health and the environment. In this work, we examine the photodegradation performance under the visible sources of BB and BG are Azo dyes extensively applied in the food and textile industries. An initial screening of dissimilar Ni-doped CdAl2O4 nanoparticles was determined to classify the most outstanding candidate for BB and BG removal. The Ni (0.075 M) doped CdAl2O4 nanoparticles after 90 min illuminations, 95 and 96% of BB and BG removal were noticed in pH =5 (acidic) and 5 mg catalyst dosage conditions. The recyclability of the Ni (0.075 M) doped CdAl2O4 catalyst was tested under optimized circumstances. The outcomes demonstrate that Ni (0.075 M) doped CdAl2O4 products exhibit substantially high stability with above 85 and 90% removal after the sixth catalytic run. The scavenging (free radicals) experiments revealed that .OH− and h + radicals play a central role in BB and BG degradation. Overall, the outcomes obtained propose that the suggested route may denote an appropriate technique for the elimination of BB and BG from textile wastes. This work shows the new pathway to improve more efficient materials for the elimination of industrial effluents.
